oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Square Dancing Fundamental: level 1, part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jan Sadlo, Sr.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Square dancing was inherited from England and France, but what makes Square Dancing truly American is the addition of the Caller. The Caller gives a dance enjoyment by phrasing calls with the music and by calling a variety of movements in interesting combinations. In this film, young dancers illustrate how to dance the movements and the fundamentals of square dancing. Dancers appearing in this films were taught by teachers Diane Baer and Nick Savannah from School District Anaheim, California.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Square dancing
Sadlo, Jan, Sr.
AIMS Instructional Media Services
Video recording

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: University of Denver
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Press Club of the University of Denver
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A weekly issue of the Clarion, published by the Press Club of the University of Denver, the official paper of the Students' Association. Editor in Chief, Charles H. Queary. Published for the benefit of Freshmen and new students. The third issue of volume 21 includes the news of the life and activities from the societies, clubs, and honor societies of the University of Denver. Also included is a column of local business advertisements.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Union Soldier Charles H. Chatfield
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Batchellor and Chatfield Family Papers, Civil War Letters of Charles H. and Clark S. Chatfield
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (letter), Poor, Envelope is 8.5 x15 cm., 31 x 20 cm
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Chatfield, Charles H.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Union Soldier Charles H. Chatfield in North Chickamauga, Georgia. 12/18/1863 Letter from Union soldier Charles H. Chatfield in North Chickamauga, George to his brother and sister in the Colorado Territory. The letter was written after the Union victory at Chattanooga. The envelope is addressed to Miss Ellen Chatfield in Beaver Creek, Tremont County, Colorado Territory.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Exterior View of Congregation Zera Abraham
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Community
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On envelope: ''#475 Labor Lyceum, Talmund Torah.'' On photograph: ''#475, Labor Lyceum, photographed by Charles McNamara, 1979.''
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McNamara, Charles
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Congregation Zera Abraham was originally organized as a Chassidic Orthodox Jewish congregation in 1877, making it the oldest congregation on the west side of Denver, Colorado. The building shown here at Julian Street and West Conejos Place was the congregation's second home. It was purchased in 1938 from the Workmen's Circle, which originally erected the building as the Labor Lyceum, an educational center. The congregation later moved to a third location on Winona Court.
Description taken from the accession record.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 64.
ph475
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Labor Lyceum (Denver, Colo.)
Congregation Zera Abraham (Denver, Colo.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tefillin for the Head
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A tefillin (phylactery) for the head consisting of a black leather box with a brown leather strap. The top of tefillin box has one section in Hebrew that designates ''shel rosh'' (for the head). These leather boxes are those which Jewish men from the age of 13 bind with leather straps on the crest of their foreheads during the morning prayers; the leather box contains parchments on which are written the four sections of the Torah in which they are mentioned: ''And you shall bind them for a sign upon your hand and for a remembrance between your eyes'' (Exodus 13:9, and with slight variations in Exodus13:16, Deuteronomy 6:8 and 11:18). Originally belonged to the Ostrover Shul (Synagogue).
Title supplied by archivist.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Religion
Jews
Ostrover Shul (Synagogue)
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Ostrover Synagogue Records, Religious Objects

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Torah Dedication at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 3 inches, black and white
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten on envelope: ''#462 JCRS Patient Activities''. Stamped on back of photograph: ''May 23 1938 Bri-Tone Prints Trade Mark Reg. Denver.'' Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Torah Dedication.''

Torah Dedication at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside Denver.
Title supplied by archivist.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.
ph462

Torah Dedication Ceremony of the synagogue of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). Unidentified men and women are seated in the audience. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Miriam Milstein Seated
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Individuals
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5.5 x 4 inches, black and white
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Miriam Milstein, 1890s.''

Miriam Milstein sits at a table with a tapestry behind her. Mrs. Milstein's husband was Shul Baer Milstein, an early leader in Denver, Colorado's west side Orthodox Jewish community, and Congregations Zera Abraham. Shul Baer Milstein was the patriarch of Cotopaxi Colony, an agricultural community located near Cotopaxi, Colorado that failed in 1884. The couple never lived in the Cotopaxi community.
Title supplied by archivist.
Provenance is unknown.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Billie Stein and Her Harmony Girls Orchestra
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Community
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten on back: ''Circa 1930, Billie Stein's Harmony Girl's Orchestra, Denver Colo, #1126, Billie Stein far right.'' On envelope: ''#1126 Billie (Lillian) Stein Collection''.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: W. Wellington Studios
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Billie (Lillian) Stein and her all-girl orchestra, The Harmony Girls, dressed as cowgirls, pose for a group portrait. Billie Stein is on the far right. Billie Stein started her own all-girls band at the age of 14 and traveled throughout the United States performing on her trumpet.
Title supplied by archivist.
Donated by Billie Stein.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civilizing the West: Early Colorado Jews in the Arts, 1865-1950
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: University of Denver.--Center for Judaic Studies
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 4 3/4 inches
Brief biographies of Jewish artists, musicians, composers, and conductors in Colorado. Jewish influence on arts in Colorado.
This program was produced through the generous support of: Mizel Global Cultural Fund and The Faye and Charles Schayer Endowment Fund.
